Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
It's sad because all the hate the Hobbit Films get, yes they are flawed but the reason they are flawed is the real crime. With LOTR, it was Jackson and his team and all the time he needed, the Hobbit was Jackson...after Del Toro dropped out, it was Jacksons team.... with 5 studios calling for changes and the time pressure to fit a deadline set by the 5 studios.
Lindsey Ellis goes into this in detail but if The Hobbit had been all Jacksons from the start, with all the time he needed and no outside creative restrictions, we would have easily had films as good as the Rings Trilogy.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I really like this movie, but I wish the intro in Bree was cut, and the last 15 minutes was Smaug attacking Laketown instead of the Dwarven forge sequence.
The thin about the intro to this film is it's lazy to just dump exposition on the viewer at the start, even if they've never seen the first one. You can mostly piece it together anyway. It annoys me everytime I start watching this movie- the very next scene is a much better place to start- Bilbo peaking over the rock and seeing their pursuers. The questions a viewer would have are not a bad thing. End rant. I like the movie quite a bit, but it's odd that the beginning and the end feel tacked on.

Comment: The one scene in this movie that defines why this Hobbit movie sucks: The part in the book where Bilbo stabs the spider in mirkwood, names sting, and the rest of that part is Bilbo's transformation from Baggins to Took and becoming more of an adventurer and saves the dwarves. Probably the most important part of the book, as far as character development goes (which is pretty important because it's about THE HOBBIT!). But instead, we see that scene replaced with a scene of Bilbo loosing the ring and becoming all possessive and brutally killing a creature to get it back. And then instead of Bilbo saving the day, ELVES DO! There is just way to much Lord of the Rings stuff, and that's why I cannot like this movie.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment: As a movie it isn't bad but for me and those who have grown up reading and enjoying The Hobbit,it is mostly a disappointment. I envy those who can say 'It was the best move ever!!' who have never read the books. Sadly, I cannot. I expect some level of faithfulness to the source material and DoS deviated so badly from the book, it is virtually unrecognizable as Tolkien. Bilbo and Smaug's encounter is the most impressive part of this film and the most faithful. The rest is a bastardized version from the overly ambitious and pompous mind of Peter Jackson. Like The Two Towers of LotR, DoS is so far from Tolkien it is painful to be a fan and have to watch this.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
These movies, including lotr ARE childish. Face the facts, the stories don't show the pain of adult life, the temptations and conflicts that responsible adults REALLY face, nor is it realistic. But they sometimes portray intense moments that are climatic, with scenes of decision making, facing challenges, breakdown etc....so it sets a great moral and message with its literature at the end of the day. So as a young adult, despite of what I said, I LOVE IT. But if someone finds it too fantasy-like and doesn't like the films (even lotr), I doesn't disagree with you one bit. But if an adult likes it and understands it, why not? Die hard fans should not bash at ¬†people who don't find these interesting, because fantasy is too subjective, and fans are immature if they disagree with the haters of the series.

But as a film and literature maniac, I LOVED it. For its intense suspense, great morals and messages, and brilliant character portrayals, references and judgements. Great work by Tolkien and Jackson!

So I just wanted to say that I have recently began an interest in reading The Hobbit/Lord of the Rings.
But before so, I wanted to make sure that I get a good copy that has dealt with most of the grammatical errors and stuff like that left behind by Tolkien.
I am probably going to get the 60th anniversary edition of The Lord of the Rings when it comes out this June since it will have the most up to date revising.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
This upsets me. With LOTR, Peter Jackson managed to squeeze all the most important things in three long, detailed books with lots of back stories into three movies: it was a great job. But The Hobbit and The Desolation of Smaug are just a embarrassing.

The first movie is basically about everyone amazingly surviving high falls and all kinds of danger - and it's not just once, but over and over again. Not to talk about this one. NOTHING is like in the books. I can't think of one scene in the whole movie that's either exaggerated with violence or completely different. For example: the elves didn't play parkour on the spiders' webs, Legolas didn't surf on one orch, nor did he jump on the dwarfes heads while shooting orchs, Bombur did NOT do his super barrel spin-attack and Thorin sure as hell didn't balance on Smaug's gap.

Let me tell you how the meeting of Smaug went in the books: Bilbo went in and took some gold to show the dwarfes and when he went back in, he awoke Smaug, who got angry and flew around the mountain trying to smash the dwarfes dead inside the tunnel - and THEN he went to Lake Town. They hid in there for several days and never even saw the dragon, so no they didn't go out to run around or light the furnaces and do they amazing stunts.¬†And oh, the love story. Of course there has to be one. Even though there wasn't one in the book.
SPOILER: they never got chased by Azog and his pack in the book, either!

My point is not to hate - I'm just mad. Peter Jackson had an amazing story and he's a good director so he COULD have done it the right way by skipping all the unnecessary action parts and stuck to the original story, because it is great already. This is disrespectful towards Tolkien.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment: Such a terrible movie. The CGI ruins everything. It felt like when they were in the city, it was almost like a play with the terrible background. Smaug was alright, since CGI was accepted for him. Also, anyone else find that Tauriel didn't speak that much and relied too much of just face expressions? Oh! And when Smaug and Bilbo were fighting and the camera cuts to almost every character with the, "What was that!?" look? That was really cheesy.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Peter Jackson did let us down. The fact that there are a lot related writings to the Hobbit can in no way beused as a reason to justify 3 movies since the changes are for the most part completely different from the other original writings. Look .. I get that a movie director should have some leeway in changing the story .. I even like the elvish warrior lady Tauriel ‚Ä¶ but so many of the changes are simply stupid ‚Ä¶ Gandalf goes off to this mountain to meet Radagast?! Because? Did they really need to go there to decide to go to Dol Guldur? And what exactly does Gandalf hope to accomplish? In the book there was an actual battle, an attack by the forces of the White Council. Why not do just that?! It would be far cooler than Gandalf getting stuck hanging in a bird cage.
Peter Jackson has transformed the story of the Hobbit so much that it scarcely resembles the original. It is not that none of the changes do not work, many in fact do, but for every 1 that does, there are 3 others which are simply laughably stupid. And it is these stupid ones, and there are scores of these, that basically ruined the movie for me.
So Smaug is fighting 10 dwarves and 1 hobbit, all unarmed, and cannot kill a single one? So he goes to Lake Town rather than simply continue the fight with these unarmed foes? Why in the world would Smaug leave the dwarves and Bilbo in possession of the Erebor and its staggering treasure so he could make an attack on Esgaroth, a place he could attack and obliterate any time after he kills and eats the dwarves and one hobbit? There are so many of these staggering dumb plot devices like this that it is just shameful that Tolkien‚Äôs name has to be associated with this pile of golden dung. We can only hope that someday some director with a bit more class and common sense and artistic integrity, will give a far better interpretation of a classic fantasy story rather than mangling one into something absolutely pathetic. And I won‚Äôt even go into the Hanna Barbara cartoon physics that seem to operate every time the dwarves encounter foes, destroying any last vestige of dignity or parallel world Tolkien intentionally created over 6 decades of his life.
Three movies? Three movies and so many characters never are even fully developed like over half the dwarves and Beorn.
The truth is this trilogy is more about more money than anything else, and never about getting it right or otherwise Bilbo would actually be major hero in the movie rather than an afterthought.
Peter Jackson does not understand nor care about Tolkien‚Äôs work no matter how much he professes otherwise. I only wish the real JRR Tolkien were here to shred him personally into ‚Äúquivering ribbons‚Äù verbally with his razor sharp wit. See The Letters of JRR Tolkien for a sample review of Tolkien‚Äôs for a proposed movie script during his lifetime.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Smaug started off incredible and utterly terrifying. A true wonder of power and spectacle.

But then the Dwarves came in and it all went south.

The Dwarves, who's main skill up until that point is being repeatedly defeated and captured, were somehow able to avoid Smaug, the chief calamity. Smaug brags about being able to smell dwarves but moments later he strolls right by them without noticing, Thorin literally stands on Smaug's nose and lives. Smaug, who committed dwarven genocide and destroyed an entire city, can't seem to catch a few dwarves withing reach and the 'furnace with wings' seems to constantly forget he can breath fire. Then Thorin surfs a shield down a molten river and remains unharmed and stands on a huge golden statue that for some reasons burst into a river and drowns Smaug. Smaug lost all sense of wonder and power.

I wish all of what I wrote was a bad joke, but it's not. Peter Jackson really did give us Smaug the Stupendous ... and then quickly gave us Smaug the Incompetent. A true disappointment.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Despite it being about 20% accurate to the book, I loved it. I enjoyed the parts Peter Jackson added in himself and loved how it followed the same events of the book, but altered them to make it fresh and new.¬†
If the film had been done completely accurately to the book then instead of the exciting and amazing barrel scene it would have just been a short scene of the Dwarves locked into barrels going down a river. Also Legolas and Tauriel actually fit in really well considering neither of them were in the book (even though Legolas would have been there as Tolkien stated)
Basically the majority of (shitty) critic reviews seemed just like rants on how it isn't accurate to the book and how it isn't as dark as TLOTR, despite scenes such as where Legolas hammered an Orcs head into a beam slowly chipping bits of his skull away.
All in all I loved the book and I loved the film, mainly because I didn't go into the film looking for flaws like so many others have done.Ôªø

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Never been so let down as when I saw this. Love all the ''this is perfect!''.. ''this is amazing!!'..you can tell they haven't even read the bloody book! Oh dear what have they done to the Hobbit!! *may have spoilers*

really was looking forward to the character 'Beorn' (one of my ¬†favourites) with a course thick black beard, big, strong very blunt and direct, confident and someone the enemy very much fears for good reason.. fantastic character in the story.
:this passage from the book..¬†

''Standing near was a huge man with a thick black beard and hair, and great bare arms and legs with knotted muscles. He was clothed in a tunic of wool down to his knees, and was leaning on a large axe.''

so how on earth in the film did the text translate to a feeble uncharismatic tall skinny werewolf thing?!?!..and that's his human form?!?! if it wasn't for the ¬£10 ticket and all the peoples hard work making the film who had no influence over the story/character design I think I could of quire easily left! just felt infuriated!¬†

20% of the book is based in an incredibly evil wood named 'Merkwood' with great adventures, fear, strange creatures and working as a team to overcome hunger and problems solving getting across vast rivers that bring us closer to the characters such as great empathy towards Bombur¬†..days where lost in this dim, dark and very creepy places found within this very strange wood and what happened to the dwarfs ¬†getting poisoned??¬†

In the film the characters walk around a wood like there tripping on bloody mushrooms for 10 minutes then it's all over? The small woodland path where Frodo has his first encounter with a ringwraith in 'the fellowship' has more Mirkwood qualities then this one! ¬†¬†

the props such as Dale and so forth where very well done in the film and Smaug looks stunning but they have changed so much of the story? characters and all the very needed rich beautiful details? In this you're left with something that dose not even come close to the book! I'm all up for slight changes for film adaptation but this has gone far to much with vast plot holes that are explained in the book but go unanswered in the film? seems like all efforts are going to smaug and the climax for the battle of the five armies and there skimping on the rest! great for family entertainment, or people that are easily impressed by mindless action and matte paintings. The real shame about this is that the story has very diverse characters¬†and depth but has not even been touched on. This is a classic story for a reason, I fear after seeing giant great statues of gold and huge barrel battle sequence with elves and orcs that the next generation will be disappointed at there disappearance in the book as this was all fictitious on the part of the film.. but there again the sort that are just interested in the 'bigger is better' rather then a good solid and fascinating storytelling with characters that will invoke fear, love, admiration, anger along with many other emotions will not be interested¬†in the real story to begin with. ¬† ¬† ¬†
¬† ¬†¬†

Comment:
¬†IMHO there's a couple of problems with the Hobbit Trilogy.
1)¬† These movies need an intermission.¬† I mean, the first film was nearly three hours long.¬† It would have been nice to have a ten minute break to stretch the legs, grab a smoke, refill the popcorn.
2) The references to Sauron.¬† Anyone who has seen LOTR already knows where this is leading so the suspense factor just isn't there.
That being said, The Hobbit is a worthy companion to LOTR.¬† Jackson outdid himself by not only telling of Bilbo's journey but cramming in everything Middle Earth into what could have been a single movie and I'm glad he did.

Comment: So much obvious CGI... Don't get me wrong: Of course these days, something like Smaug cannot be done using animatronics and stuff like that ‚Äì I do not have my head on backwards when it comes to new technology ‚Äì but what happened to the AWESOME miniature sets and makeup they used in the LOTR trilogy? This starts looking way too much like the Star Wars prequels: Flashy stuff, impossible pans, lot of shit going on in every shot, yet there's just no life to any of it... everything's way too "squeaky-clean"... And most importantly: Why all that digital colour timing? Do movies these days HAVE to be all blue and orange?

Comment:
True movies have to vary from books but the number and extent of changes were far too great. Thorin was never heroic, Radagast is not deranged, that orc leader is historically incorrect and the elves never saw the attack on Misty Mountain. Personally I want this movie to succeed so that it takes the Tolkien Lord of the Rings world further. But I also wish Jackson wouldn't completely rework the plot and saddle it with that dreadful 48 fps.
I appreciate your criticism, was expecting trolling

They took the book the Hobbit, a prequel to the LOTR trilogy, and are making it into it's own trilogy. The first, An Unexpected Journey, has already came out. The second, this one (Desolation of Smaug), is coming out. There will be a third next year.

They mixed the Hobbit with parts of the The Silmarillion- a lot of the added material is from that.
Some of the extra plot points which are from neither have been added to better tie the Lord of the Rings movie trilogy to these movies.

Also, I don't understand why people continue to get upset when movie versions so fucking rarely match the books.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment: Well... Jackson had to do *something* with the movie. The actual Hobbit book is actually pretty dry. They walk to the mountain, make the dragon mad, and basically watch while someone else kills it. It actually makes for a pretty boring book from a pacing point of view. So if you're going to make a movie, you have to find stuff to add. The Silmarillion, a companion book released after the trilogy, fills in all the backstory behind the world of Middle-Earth. That's what's in these movies.

1/2 that comment was stupid. ill list the reasons why.

Comment: ... that was sarcasm.  The dwarves were digging for commodity currency.  I've already established that.  The most valuable piece of commodity currency they found was the arkenstone, which is why Thorin wanted it so badly.  In the films, Thrain used it to justify his power by taking it "as a sign, a sign that his right to rule was divine."  This gave it great symbolic meaning above that of instrumental value.  In that regard, in the books, the dwarves are MORE GREEDY than in the films.

Comment: It's not so much arrogance, as just not liking dwarves. The Silmarillion goes into detail about the grudge between elves & dwarves. The dwarves believe that the elven king was the one who tried to kill the smiths, who were dwarven, that crafted the Nauglamir for him, which led to his death. Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment: Legolas is never actually mentioned in the book, but Bilbo and the dwarves do enter the elven kingdom in Mirkwood. Thranduil is the elvenking who rules that kingdom. He is in the book and he is Legolas's father. Tolkein's timeline shows that Legolas was alive at the time the events of The Hobbit took place so it makes sense to assume that he was around even though he wasn't actually mentioned in the book.

The reason why it "looks" worse or not as good is because in LOTR and movies made between the 2000 - 2005 (around here) the CGI blended well in films. Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment:
The Smaug we see here is from a dream-sequence, and is rather a representation of what Bilbo -thinks- Smaug (rather, a dragon) looks like.

Notice that Bilbo is wearing his evening robe, rather than any of the clothes he actually -brought with him- on his journey; his dream probably starts out with him safe, and at home... and then reality comes crashing down into his dream; he's going to -steal- from a -dragon-.

And that, my dear fellow... is far from -safe-.

Comment:
Bard was a bit more important. He is the descendent of the ancient king of Dale, and a leader among the humans. And he kills Smaugh with the help of a thursh who tells him his weak spot that Bilbo had discovered.
In the movie, I know they're keeping him, and are actually giving him a more proper introduction (he's the long haired man we can see talking with elves). Now I don't know if they'll keep the whole talking to birds stuff, but who knows. We already saw another bird warning Smaug, anyway.

Comment: Actually no, there's no evidence that he lived before the year 1000 of the Third Age. Legolas states in The Fellowship that he's never been to Lorien before. Legolas was probably born after that event. Considering the War of the Ring happened about 3019, he shouldn't be any older than 2019.

Comment:
No. He's most likely between 3,000 and 5,500 years old, born sometime in the Second Age, based on circumstantial evidence from Tolkien's writings and letters. There is no concrete evidence for Legolas' age. "2030" is a made up number which New Line published.

He is certainly a mature elf, though, in the Two Towers he makes two references to his age, one in Fangorn forest and one at Meduseld in Edoras. But in terms of other Elves in the series, he's far from ancient.

Most consistently critics seem to have an issue with it's length, and it's frame rate.

I disagree. I think it was a good decision.

1) At The Battle of the 5 Armies, there needs to be a clear differentiation in motivation between the goblins and the wargs. Having the wargs fight the battle simply because "their leader was killed" is a bit weak from a movie standpoint. They also need an instigator, aka Azog.
2) The dwarves needs pushing from behind to keep the danger levels high and the story flowing.
3) Azog adds weight to Thorin's mentality and motivation.

Some of the best movies ever made have major differences from the books they are based on. There are cases like World War Z where they literally took the name of the book and told a completely different story, and there are cases like the Hobbit where changes were made that only anger people who want the exact same story over and over again in every format.

Comment: Completely forgivable.  I'm not agreeing with the previous posters, merely pointing out that the original animated version was well done, with a great soundtrack, amazing voice acting and (nearly) top-notch animation.  It's one of the films that made me realize that cartoons and animation in general are an art form and not just 22 minute distractions for kids after school and on Saturday morning.  I still kind of take offense to "cringe-worthy" because it implies that any part of that is bad.

Title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug - Official Teaser Trailer [HD]
Comment: Yeah, I get that, but I just don't think the characters from LotR should be shoved into the hobbit where they don't belong. It's not that I don't like the characters, (although I never found Legolas particularly compelling,) and it's not that I mind them taking liberties with the book, (I actually really loved the first movie,) but when they transplant characters from LotR to The Hobbit, it's kind of obvious that they don't belong, and we don't get as much focus on the new ones we love as well.

Comment:
Completely agree. Certain things work much better for the big screen, that wouldn't, and in some cases can't, for the book. 

As far as pacing goes, the hobbit is famous for it's "2 weeks went by..." moments, where huge narrative is ignored that Peter can elaborate on. A perfect example will be the battle of the 5 armies. In the book, the armies assembling and Bolg approaching is a small paragraph, whereas in the movie this could easily inhabit 10 minutes of eye candy!

Comment: Jackson's decision to do three films was sound. The Hobbit is short in page count, but huge and epic in sweep and feel. I have the great books, not I am getting great films. Different experiences, different approaches.

Comment:
I'm thinking that the CG F/X are not finished, here. The dragon looks weak--especially his eyes. The book said his eyes shown like lamps or lanterns, lighting up areas of the cavern floor. There's no external illumination going on here, at all. And the internal illumination is simplistic. Those eyes look cheap, like a low-budget made-for-TV effect.

There's still a long time before the Dec. release, so the look of that dragon will probably (hopefully) be improved between now and then.

Comment: Legolas is the prince of Mirkwood. In the book, Bilbo and the dwarves are taken prisoner by the elves there. While the character hadn't been invented yet when The Hobbit was written, there's no reason they can't retroactively say he was there. The easiest way to explain why he doesn't appear in the book is that Bilbo doesn't know who he is, so he'd be just another elf who gets no special attention.

Comment:
Legolas wasn't in the Hobbit, but he most certainly was around during the events of the Hobbit. Plus, Thranduil (spelling?) is his father, so it makes sense that he could make an appearance. As does the more in-depth storyline with the Necromancer, if they're connecting the story more with Lord of the Rings, he's kind of an important detail.

As for Smaug, he's covered in shadow, I don't see how you can judge the CG by the trailer. I'm sure when they show more detail, he'll look better.

"The Hobbit" was written before Tolkien even foreseen writing LOTR.  In "The Hobbit," the ring was just a ring that turns people invisible, but obviously Tolkien himself "edited" or reshaped the ring to be the One Ring.  Same way with Thranduil and his son.  In the book, if I recall, he is just called the "Elvenking" but in the LOTR he is given the name Thranduil and his son is Legolas.

If you had a son, wouldn't you expect him to be in your kingdom?

So much of what's wrong with the first film is still present here. As for Smaug... not very compelling or scary. It's disturbing that LotR's visuals from over a decade ago are superior to The Hobbit's.
